content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-049-15-B |Item_parent=Normal and pathological puberty |Item_parent_short=Normal and pathological puberty |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the biological test to prescribe in the case of proven precocious puberty |Description=None |Rubric=Etiologies |Contributors= |Order=15}} Sex steroids: testosterone in boys, oestradiol of little contribution in girls. Inhibin B: increased during puberty in boys. Gonadotropins: basal FSH and LH and after stimulation (LH-RH/GnRH test). Used to diagnose and distinguish between central (detectable LH, peak LH) and peripheral (undetectable LH) precocious puberty. Bone age: assessment of bone maturation (onset of puberty=sesamoid at 11 years in girls and 13 years in boys). It is most often advanced in early puberty.

properties.question: Which biological test is most appropriate for diagnosing and distinguishing between central and peripheral precocious puberty?
properties.option_a: Measurement of testosterone levels in boys
properties.option_c: LH-RH/GnRH stimulation test for basal FSH and LH levels
